content:
A couple remarks.

- You can pass all tests and fail validator 8. Example code: https://bpa.st/LISNO
- I don't think it is entirely clear if the global negative lookahead also follows the use of brackets only if there is more than one character. That is, should the answer of

1
clash GGGG_

be

^(?!.*[h])clas.$ or
^(?!.*h)clas.$

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: accept this contribution
ðŸ‘

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good game, had fun

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Updating approval.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The contribution is an interesting way to tackle the challenge of RegEx, I would however recommend renaming some of the validators which are called "Validator N".

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: As I said before, good puzzle and the statement offers a good explanation.
I knew a little about regex, but the positive and negative look-ahead was something new to me (or at least I didn't remember it) and I had no problem solving it thanks to the statement.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Un bon casse-tÃªte !
assez complexe mais qui me plait bien

The puzzle is quite straightforward and the rules are very well defined.
That said, I feel the rules can be slightly improved: for letters that have a one yellow position and gray positions, I don't see why it would not need to be excluded from gray positions aside from making the puzzle easier.

Taking validator 8 for example, as s is forbidden in 5th position, should not it be:
^(?=.*s)(?!.*[cdginouwy]).hel(?![es]).$, instead of 
^(?=.*s)(?!.*[cdginouwy]).hel(?!e).$

Take in mind I'm no regEx expert and  this is just my two cents. The extra complexity is not too much I feel.

Also, could we not add a positive look-ahead for repeats if we know the word has repeated letters, instead of ignoring if we see gray and other colored positions, say if s has at least 2 occurrences:
(?=.*s.*s)
3 occurrences: (?=.*s.*s.*s)
these would be used if not all green positions for the letter have been found.

That aside, medium difficulty is quite fitting.

Good puzzle. 
The puzzle is easy, but it requires (at least for me) more lines of code than an easy puzzle normally requires, so I think the medium difficulty is fine.
About the stament, although it is long, it seems to me that it explains well the details that must be taken into consideration, which makes it possible to solve it even without knowing regEx.
Really nice experience, would love to see more such problems!

I like it but aren't you giving too much insight in the statement ?
I think you should give terms that people could search.

Hello,

What I like: it's about regex ;)
What I less like:
regex are a world of freedom (perhaps am I overdoing it?), with always various ways to write them.
But here we have to follow one specific schema, which give me a strange feeling of constraint.
For example, what if I prefer to use a negative char class rather than a negative look-ahead?

Anyway, nice puzzle, upvoted.

About the difficulty, and if you think about people not knowing regex, medium seems appropriate.

I'm interested to know if people think that "Medium" is appropriate difficulty for this. I can't find guidelines on what separates Medium from Easy.

I have chosen Medium for now because of the time it takes to understand the problem. I think coding it is actually relatively easy, but the puzzle here lies largely in comprehending the problem and the way the solution is structured.

Happy to change to Easy if several people think that is more appropriate.

Goal
* 3rd bullet point: "â€¦ then the start of your RegEx will then be â€¦": Suggest to delete the second "then".

* Please fix the typo: elligible => eligible.

* 6th bullet point: "(?![der]])": Please delete the extra "]".

* Examples: Suggest to format the input as monospace at the same time, e.g. the first one becomes:
<<Example 1>>
```{{2
paper ___G_
boils _G___}}```
<<Answer>>

Constraints
* The last two cases violate the first constraint. Please fix the constraint and/or the cases.

Cases
* Test 6 (Everything): Suggest to revise the case to make it more similar to Validator 6.

* Test 8 (What Could It Be?): Suggest to revise the case to make it more similar to Validator 8, or split the pair into two pairs (i.e. add a new test and a new validator to pair up with the original cases).

Thanks.

Wow, thanks a ton. Great eye for detail, as always.

Implemented all of them.

Moved Test 7 (Don't Exclude all the Grays) to a new Test 10 position. Made Test 7 into a split of Test 6 (Everything) into 2 better matching tests/validator pairs. Named it "Everything Everywhere".

Moved Test 9 (Don't Exclude all the Grays) to a new Test 10 position. Made Test 9 into a split of Test 8 (What Could It Be?) into 2 better matching tests/validator pairs. Named it "Everything Everywhere, All At Once".

I agree with your rationale for setting the difficulty of this puzzle to Medium.

For your reference, I find the rules of thumb by another moderator (Wontonimo) quite useful for my assessment of the difficulty level of a puzzle.

His rules of thumb for difficulty are as follows: 
* if/else and possibly a loop is 'easy'.  
* Recursion, DFS, BFS, Minimax is 'medium'.  
* Something brute-forceable is easy or medium.
* Tricky or mathy stuff with multiple steps is 'hard' or 'very hard'
* Very hard: mini research projects requiring a lot of local coding and own test case development

Yeah, I get your criticism with this rigid schema being antithetical to what RegEx is all about. However, since there needs to be a single correct answer for each test, I had to force a solution here.

The idea is that people who don't know RegEx can get a feel for it and see how useful it is, and then can get creative on their own once they warm up to it. :)
Mmm, perhaps. I like my statements to be self-contained, but it is pretty long. I'll see if I can leave some parts of it to people to further Google..
Thanks, I'm glad for this feedback. It's good to know that you can solve it without knowing RegEx. :)

Yeah, I considered going all the way with this but I felt like the added complexity wasn't worth it in terms of the solver's enjoyment.
It feels much more elegant when you don't include the complex rules, and I didn't want solving it to end up getting too messy either.

I'm glad you enjoyed. :)
Hopefully I can get you to approve again, now it's up for a second attempt at getting 3.

Thanks for the approval. Hopefully it can get 3 this time with your help, back to 0 for now.

I left the validator names as default, because users won't see them anyway, but I know it can look jarring in the IDE while evaluating.

Would you please state the reasons for your approval and not just mention that you accept a contribution in the future?

Also, I notice that you've approved 6 contributions in a row. Have you really tried to solve the contributions and write your own solutions before you approve them? Please don't approve them if you have not done so yet.

Thanks for spotting, I've now made it so that code will fail Test: "Don't exclude all grays 2":
3
assay YY___
plate __G__
shack __GY_
^(?=.*c)(?=.*s)(?!.*[ehklpty])(?!a).(?!s).a(?!c)..$

I've also emphasised that the negative lookaheads only are grouped in brackets if there are multiple.

It's true for clashes that users cannot see the names of validators, but it's not the case for puzzles. For puzzles, players can see the names after submission of their code by clicking RESULTS > MY REPORT > SCORE > DETAILS.

But in neither puzzles nor clashes will people see the validator names while solving it. Being able to see them after solving is fine, and I think having them simply numbered is useful to differentiate them from tests, personally. Most important thing is that they won't be visible for anyone while solving, and only ever seen by the minority of people who choose to look into the details afterwards.

Renamed test 8 from (What Could It Be?) to (Don't Exclude ALL Grays!), made test 8 (Don't Exclude ALL Grays!) into (Don't Exclude ALL Grays! 2), because I realised test 8 was the first time this issue of some gray letters also being green or yellow was tested now.
